defs.docs:
minifb is a cross platform library written in [Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org) that makes it
 easy to open windows (usually native to the running operating system) and can optionally show
 a 32-bit buffer. minifb also support keyboard, mouse input and menus on selected operating
 systems.

attributes.value: / minifb is a cross platform library written in [Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org) that makes it
/ easy to open windows (usually native to the running operating system) and can optionally show
/ a 32-bit buffer. minifb also support keyboard, mouse input and menus on selected operating

defs.name: FitScreen
defs.docs:
This mode checks your current screen resolution and will caluclate the largest window size
 that can be used within that limit and resize it. Useful if you have a small buffer to
 display on a high resolution screen.

attributes.value: / This mode checks your current screen resolution and will caluclate the largest window size
/ that can be used within that limit and resize it. Useful if you have a small buffer to
/ display on a high resolution screen.

defs.name: X1
defs.docs: 1X scale (which means leave the corrdinates sent into Window::new untouched)

attributes.value: / 1X scale (which means leave the corrdinates sent into Window::new untouched)

defs.name: X2
defs.docs: 2X window scale (Example: 320 x 200 -> 640 x 400)

defs.name: X4
defs.docs: 4X window scale (Example: 320 x 200 -> 1280 x 800)

defs.name: X8
defs.docs: 8X window scale (Example: 320 x 200 -> 2560 x 1600)

defs.name: X16
defs.docs: 16X window scale (Example: 320 x 200 -> 5120 x 3200)

defs.name: X32
defs.docs: 32 window scale (Example: 320 x 200 -> 10240 x 6400)

defs.name: Scale
defs.value: pub enum Scale { FitScreen, X1, X2, X4, X8, X16, X32, }
defs.docs:
Scale will scale the frame buffer and the window that is being sent in when calling the update
 function. This is useful if you for example want to display a 320 x 256 window on a screen with
 much higher resolution which would result in that the window is very small.

attributes.value: / Scale will scale the frame buffer and the window that is being sent in when calling the update
/ function. This is useful if you for example want to display a 320 x 256 window on a screen with
/ much higher resolution which would result in that the window is very small.

defs.name: add_char
defs.docs:
Called when text is added to the window, or a key is pressed. This passes
 in a unicode character, and therefore does not report control characters.

attributes.value: / Called when text is added to the window, or a key is pressed. This passes
/ in a unicode character, and therefore does not report control characters.

defs.name: set_key_state
defs.value: pub fn set_key_state(&mut Self, Key, bool)
defs.docs:
Called whenever a key is pressed or released. This reports the state of the
 key in the `state` argument, as well as the translated key in the `key` argument.
 This includes control characters such as `Key::LeftShift`.

attributes.value: / Called whenever a key is pressed or released. This reports the state of the
/ key in the `state` argument, as well as the translated key in the `key` argument.
/ This includes control characters such as `Key::LeftShift`.

defs.name: Icon
defs.value: pub enum Icon { Path(*const u16), Buffer(*const u64, u32), }
defs.docs: Represents a window icon

attributes.value: / Different under Windows, Linux and MacOS
/ **Windows**: Icon can be created from a relative path string
/ **Linux / X11:** Icon can be created from an ARGB buffer

defs.name: Window
defs.docs:
Window is used to open up a window. It's possible to optionally display a 32-bit buffer when
 the widow is set as non-resizable.

attributes.value: / Window is used to open up a window. It's possible to optionally display a 32-bit buffer when
/ the widow is set as non-resizable.

defs.name: Stretch
defs.docs: Stretch the buffer in the whole window meaning if your buffer is 256x256 and window is 1024x1024 it will be scaled up 4 times

attributes.value: / Stretch the buffer in the whole window meaning if your buffer is 256x256 and window is 1024x1024 it will be scaled up 4 times

defs.name: AspectRatioStretch
defs.docs: Keep the correct aspect ratio to be displayed while scaling up fully in the other axis. Fill area will be filed with Window::set_bg_color (default 0, 0, 0)

attributes.value: / Keep the correct aspect ratio to be displayed while scaling up fully in the other axis. Fill area will be filed with Window::set_bg_color (default 0, 0, 0)

defs.name: Center
defs.docs:
Places the buffer in the middle of the window without any scaling. Fills the borders with color set `Window::set_background_color` (default 0, 0, 0)
 If the window is smaller than the buffer the center of the buffer will be displayed

attributes.value: / Places the buffer in the middle of the window without any scaling. Fills the borders with color set `Window::set_background_color` (default 0, 0, 0)
/ If the window is smaller than the buffer the center of the buffer will be displayed

defs.name: UpperLeft
defs.docs: Same as Center but places the buffer in the upper left corner of the window.

attributes.value: / Same as Center but places the buffer in the upper left corner of the window.

defs.name: ScaleMode
defs.value: pub enum ScaleMode { Stretch, AspectRatioStretch, Center, UpperLeft, }
defs.docs:
On some OS (X11 for example) it's possible a window can resize even if no resize has been set.
 This causes some issues depending on how the content of an input buffer should be displayed then it's possible
 to set this scaling mode to get a better behavior.

attributes.value: / On some OS (X11 for example) it's possible a window can resize even if no resize has been set.
/ This causes some issues depending on how the content of an input buffer should be displayed then it's possible
/ to set this scaling mode to get a better behavior.

defs.name: topmost
defs.docs: Should the window be the topmost window (default: false)

defs.name: transparency
defs.docs:
Specifies whether or not the window is allowed to draw transparent pixels (default: false)
 Requires borderless to be 'true'
 TODO: Currently not implemented on OSX.
 TODO: Make it work without none option on windows.

attributes.value: / Specifies whether or not the window is allowed to draw transparent pixels (default: false)
/ TODO: Currently not implemented on OSX.
/ TODO: Make it work without none option on windows.

defs.name: none
defs.docs:
Required for transparency on windows.
 Should be mutually exclusive to resize, automatically assumes borderless.
 Not supported on OSX.

attributes.value: / Should be mutually exclusive to resize, automatically assumes borderless.

Returns the native handle for a window which is an opaque pointer/handle which
 dependens on the current operating system:

defs.name: update_with_buffer
defs.value: pub fn update_with_buffer(&mut Self, &[u32], usize, usize) -> Result<()>
defs.docs:
Updates the window with a 32-bit pixel buffer. The encoding for each pixel is `0RGB`:
 The upper 8-bits are ignored, the next 8-bits are for the red channel, the next 8-bits
 afterwards for the green channel, and the lower 8-bits for the blue channel.

attributes.value: / Updates the window with a 32-bit pixel buffer. The encoding for each pixel is `0RGB`:
/ The upper 8-bits are ignored, the next 8-bits are for the red channel, the next 8-bits
/ afterwards for the green channel, and the lower 8-bits for the blue channel.
/ Notice that the buffer needs to be at least the size of the created window. Also only one of
/ `update_with_buffer` or `update` should be called for updating a single window.
/ fn from_u8_rgb(r: u8, g: u8, b: u8) -> u32 {
/     let (r, g, b) = (r as u32, g as u32, b as u32);
/ let mut buffer: Vec<u32> = vec![azure_blue; buffer_width * buffer_height];
/ let mut window = Window::new("Test", window_width, window_height, WindowOptions::default()).unwrap();

defs.name: update
defs.docs: Updates the window (this is required to call in order to get keyboard/mouse input, etc)

attributes.value: / Updates the window (this is required to call in order to get keyboard/mouse input, etc)
/ Notice that when using this function then `update_with_buffer` should not be called for the same window.
/ Only one of the functions should be used.

defs.name: is_open
defs.docs:
Checks if the window is still open. A window can be closed by the user (by for example
 pressing the close button on the window) It's up to the user to make sure that this is
 being checked and take action depending on the state.

attributes.value: / Checks if the window is still open. A window can be closed by the user (by for example
/ pressing the close button on the window) It's up to the user to make sure that this is
/ being checked and take action depending on the state.

defs.name: topmost

Makes the window the topmost window and makes it stay always on top. This is useful if you
 want the window to float above all over windows

defs.name: set_background_color
defs.value: pub fn set_background_color(&mut Self, usize, usize, usize)
defs.docs:
Sets the background color that is used with update_with_buffer.
 In some cases there will be a blank area around the buffer depending on the ScaleMode that has been set.
 This color will be used in the in that area.
 The function takes 3 parameters in (red, green, blue) and each value is in the range of 0-255 where 255 is the brightest value

attributes.value: / Sets the background color that is used with update_with_buffer.
/ In some cases there will be a blank area around the buffer depending on the ScaleMode that has been set.
/ This color will be used in the in that area.
/ The function takes 3 parameters in (red, green, blue) and each value is in the range of 0-255 where 255 is the brightest value
/ // Set background color to bright red

defs.name: set_cursor_visibility
defs.docs:
Changes whether or not the cursor image should be shown or if the cursor image
 should be invisible inside the window
 When creating a new window the default is 'false'

attributes.value: / Changes whether or not the cursor image should be shown or if the cursor image
/ should be invisible inside the window
/ When creating a new window the default is 'false'

defs.name: limit_update_rate
defs.docs:
Limits the update rate of polling for new events in order to reduce CPU usage.
 The problem of having a tight loop that does something like this

attributes.value: / Limits the update rate of polling for new events in order to reduce CPU usage.
/ The problem of having a tight loop that does something like this
/ Is that lots of CPU time will be spent calling system functions to check for new events in a tight loop making the CPU time go up.
/ Using `limit_update_rate` minifb will check how much time has passed since the last time and if it's less than the selected time it will sleep for the remainder of it.
/ This means that if more time has spent than the set time (external code taking longer) minifb will not do any waiting at all so there is no loss in CPU performance with this feature.
/ By default it's set to 4 milliseconds. Setting this value to None and no waiting will be done
/ // Make sure that at least 4 ms has passed since the last event poll

defs.name: get_scroll_wheel
defs.docs:
Get the current movement of the scroll wheel.
 Scroll wheel can mean different thing depending on the device attach.
 For example on Mac with trackpad "scroll wheel" means two finger
 swiping up/down (y axis) and to the sides (x-axis)
 When using a mouse this assumes the scroll wheel which often is only y direction.

/ When using a mouse this assumes the scroll wheel which often is only y direction.

This allows adding menus to your windows. As menus behaves a bit diffrently depending on
 Operating system here is how it works.
